. - The speech of the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Whitlam) was like that of a person who was either apologizing for the Communist line in the cold war or actively carrying out what Mr. Khrushchev described a few days ago as the foreign policy of Russia - creating economic difficulties and doing all those things which the Communists can do through their fifth column in this country. I am sorry to say that the honorable member for Werriwa gave lip service to that policy. I regret very much that any one in the National Parliament should do that. Broadly, in apologizing for Russia's imperialism, he said that that country now had less territory in Europe and Asia than it had in 1914.
- Is that not right?

- In 1914, Russia took in the whole of Poland and Siberia. To-day, the Soviet has - in Europe and Asia - sixteen countries and 600,000,000 people enslaved in a most barbarous and horrible way. In those countries the rights of all trade unionists, except those who act as Russia's agents, have been taken away. Freedom of speech and religion no longer exist. By contrast, the Western nations Have freed at least sixteen countries and 600,000,000 people from bondage. Thus, whilst Russia has taken a very great number of people into its empire, in a most savage and repugnant fashion, the democracies have freed or prepared for freedom in countries which include Malaya and Cyprus, a number equally as great.

speech.para: The honorable member for Werriwa, in speaking as he did to-night in this House, was deliberately misleading the people into believing the things that Mr. Khrushchev wishes them to believe. He said something about Formosa, and queried whether it should receive more aid than India and Indonesia. To criticize what America is trying to do is to insult those who are endeavouring to help and protect us. I recall that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) once before reproved the honorable member for Werriwa for doing just that, and to-night he has been at it again. He said, amongst other things, that our treatment of Indonesia had been abhorrent. I believe that to be untrue. Indeed, if the people of Indonesia had not been helped by the friends of the honorable member for Werriwa, including a man named Campbell, who belongs to the Waterside Workers Federation, certain things would not have been kept on the wharfs when they should have been loaded for Indonesia, and that country would not have received selfdetermination at a time when it was not ready for it. Now there is frightful chaos in Indonesia.

As for Australia's treatment} being regarded as abhorrent in South-East Asia, I point out that it is well known that thousands of Asian students come to this country instead of going to Europe. They treat Australia as their alma mater and training ground. They carry back with them stories, which can be read in the press, of the way in which Australians treat them as equals. For the honorable member for Werriwa to say that Australia is regarded with abhorrence in
Indonesia is to do a disservice to those who are trying to carry out the Colombo plan.

The honorable member for Werriwa tried to fortify the decisions of the Hobart conference, which split the Labour party - I think that nineteen members stayed and seventeen left. I give the honorable member credit for being most uncertain about it all. He read some of his material and then quoted from notes that were passed to him while he was speaking. It seemed that he was a little unhappy about the Hobart conference. In a furtive and uncertain way, he said some things that were wrong and damaging to Australia and to the Labour party itself. I am surprised to see some one trying to carry that out.

The honorable member for Werriwa mentioned Cyprus. He said that there was nothing in the GovernorGeneral's Speech about that island. So I think that those of us who were among the Australian troops who were in Cyprus during World War II. should say something in this debate about the situation there. To know something about Cyprus one has to realize that the Balkan States, Turkey, Greece and other places, were, at the beginning of the last war, very backward countries. In Cyprus we saw an island where people were, carrying on their agricultural production with the most primitive methods. One would see a man or a woman out in the field cutting a very thin crop of wheat and bringing in the grain in the most primitive way. The wheat would be taker io the threshing floor, and a man or a woman would get on to a wooden slide drawn perhaps by a heifer or a camel, or both, and would move the slide around on the straw and wheat until the wheat was broken up in some way. Then they would throw this material up in the air so that the wind would carry away the straw. An honorable member says that they winnowed it. This rough, poor quality grain, would be gathered, and in that way they got their food. There was not enough food in Cyprus in the war, and Australian fare had to be brought in. It was indeed very welcome to the Cypriots. I remember how the Cypriots would exclaim with enthusiasm over bread that had been made from choice Australian flour or good Australian wheat which would not be considered of high quality in Australia, but was considered of very high quality in Cyprus because it was so much better than their own. They would say, "Here, try a piece of Australian bread ". They were very glad indeed to get it, despite the fact that it was made from wheat that was of poor quality in Australian eyes.

Cyprus and the surrounding countries generally, the Lebanon, Syria, Palestine, Greece itself and the Anatolian plateau in Turkey, were very backward indeed. What I want to impress upon the House is that the British Government in its administration of Cyprus, which it administers as a Crown colony, has done a magnificent job. This work has been carried out directly under the control of British officers in charge of Cyprus who, even during the war, were beginning to promote co-operatives, establish a system of loans to farmers, and so on. Cyprus was then principally an agricultural country, but it now has a very large asbestos works, a copper smelting works, and mines. It now exports about £10,000 worth of minerals a year. During the British Government's programme to rehabilitate and revolutionize the Cypriot agricultural economy 20,000 windmills and wells were put into operation as a result of British agricultural loans to the people and farmers of Cyprus.

On Cyprus there is a large, dry plain where the heat in summer is tremendous, rising to as high as 130 degrees every day. There was a great shortage of water there, although water was to be had at a depth of about 20 feet below the plain throughout the whole area. That water was needed badly for the production of crops and the rearing of animals, and the British Government had a scheme for lending farmers enough money to put in a windmill and a well.

talk.start.para: - Then can the honorable member explain why the Cypriots want the British to get out?

- I shall come to that in a moment. The British Government has done in Cyprus what it did in India and has done in Malaya. It has | made a tremendous contribution to the j economy and the well-being of Cyprus. | When the Venetians and others were in possession of Cyprus they took for themselves two-thirds of the revenue produced on the island. But the British Government has not only spent the whole of the revenue from Cyprus on the island itself, but has also contributed from Her Majesty's Exchequer large sums for the assistance of the Cypriots. I think that this year, or last year, it spent the very large amount of £500,000 on earthquake relief measures. There is a tremendous number of agricultural officers carrying out extension services in Cyprus. In fact, there are at least 100 of them, which is more than the number of such officers at work in New South Wales. There are about 500,000 people in Cyprus. The officers include veterinary officers, and they are doing a magnificent job in advising the Cypriot people on how to improve their agriculture. There is a long list of improvements that have been carried out since 1941. Here was a country dry and hard, a desert in the summer, which has now been made to blossom. The list of agricultural services provided by the British is much more extensive and elaborate than is the list of facilities provided by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture for farmers in that State. It includes efficient extension services farms, stations, nurseries and stud stables which are of direct benefit to farmers and stock breeders ; development of a co-operative or group approach to the small holding or landless shepherd problem; earth-moving equipment, advice on conservation and improved use of land; encouragement, where desirable, of diversified husbandry of live-stock; orderly marketing and seed quality consciousness. [Quorum formed.] The list also includes trials of improved live-stock and farm crop varieties; trial and demonstration of practical plant protection; further tree planting, including planting of carob trees, citrus, olives, table grapes and deciduous fruit tree3. An amazing tree which grows in Cyprus is called the carob. I have seen examples of it here in some of our botanical gardens. This tree gives a huge yield of beans which provide stock feed, glue, sugar and a great many other things. It is of immense importance to Cyprus.
- What has all this to do with a debate on foreign affairs?

- I should not expect the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) to know, because the Labour party does not seem to worry about how an undeveloped country should be helped and made ready for selfdetermination. Improved farming methods and machinery have been assisted and there has been an improvement of grazing and fodder resources, as well as a study of the problems of animal nutrition. The Labour party apparently wants to throw a country that is not ready for selfdetermination and self-government into the lap of the gods before it is ready to stand on its own feet, when it would be an easy prey to communism, but, of course, I would not expect the honorable member for East Sydney to consider that aspect at all.

speech.para: Cyprus poses many problems for the Cypriots themselves. Those of us who were there know that there was a very strong and very healthy Turkish minority problem in Cyprus. Most of the Turkish inhabitants are people of tremendous vigour and, incidentally, they were very friendly to us. Their interests have to be protected. But that is not a major problem, although the Turkish minority still is a problem. Cyprus is geologically a part of the Anatolian plateau. It is close to Turkey. One can see the Taurus mountains from the island of Cyprus at the port of Kyrenia, and therefore it is part of Turkey, and the Turks there ought to be considered. The Cypriots have been offered self-government. The British had sent their Foreign Secretary to Cyprus to help in any possible way, but the negotiations for self-government broke down, not on the self-determination question, but because of the obstinancy of Archbishop Makarios. The final break came when it was discovered that Archibishop Makarios and some of his people were deeply implicated in terrorism which had resulted in the murder of British troops and other people. In other words, the head of the Greek Orthodox Church there had been mixed up in terrorism of a violent kind and, therefore, he had to be deported if further trouble was to be avoided.

talk.start.para: - Is he a Communist?

- I do not know whether he is a Communist or not, but I believe that the Communists are using him, because they are clever enough to take advantage of any situation in which they can bring in a local issue. I think it was reported only this morning that the Greek Premier had said that if the United Nations did not intervene, communism might take over in Greece. So, there was the threat that if anything happened to Makarios, communism might take over.
- I am glad that the honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) is now awake. I hope it was something I said that caused him to take an interest in the debate.

speech.para: The British wanted Archbishop Makarios to await the outcome of the constitutional committee which had been appointed to inquire into the best means of giving self-government to Cyprus. That was a perfectly proper attitude and was on all fours with the situation in Malaya. That is to say, backward countries which have not had the advantage of a good public service and of good constitutional government should wait until they are ready for self-government. We have seen Malayans and Indonesians coming to Australia to look at our Public Service. I do not know whether they are prepared to. applaud it, but at least they are able to see our methods. Malaya and Indonesia are maturing politically and are becoming ready for selfgovernment. The same kind of thing is happening in Cyprus, where the British are doing everything possible to improve the country and make it ready for selfgovernment. They are going about that task so rapidly that it is almost breathtaking. Many tasks which were about to be performed when we were there in 1941, have since been done with great speed.

I think that another reason why the negotiations broke down was that the British had refused to extend the general amnesty to all terrorists. In other words, those men among the terrorists who were guilty of murder and other serious crimes were not to be given the benefit of the general amnesty in the event of the negotiations being concluded amicably. Therefore, Archbishop Makarios broke off the negotiations. With the sense of justice which the British have always had, those men were to be left outside the terms of the general amnesty and handed over to the law at the proper time. There is not the slightest doubt that British troops have been murdered in Cyprus and that that has aggravated the situation.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker, I direct your attention to tinstate of the House.

para.inline: proceeding towards the door of the chamber,

talk.start.para: .- During the course of this debate we have listened to some remarkable statements from honorable members opposite. Some of those statements have been most provocative, and others have been unwarranted and inexcusable. The outrageous statements made during the course of the debate yesterday by the honorable member for Bradfield (Mr. Turner), concerning the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt), impel me to condemnatory comment. His statements have received widespread publicity in the journals of this country, and I have no doubt thai little will be said regarding their rebuttal. The honorable member accused the Leader of the Opposition of having betrayed Australia. I think that it is outrageous that such a statement should be made about a man who occupies the distinguished and honorable position of Leader of the Opposition in this Parliament, particularly when that man is most highly regarded in the councils of international affairs, and his life and record has been one of service to this country. It ill-becomes an honorable member, possessed of much less knowledge and dignity, to express himself in the way in which the honorable member spoke of the Leader of the Opposition yesterday. I believe that the honorable member for Bradfield will live to regret the statements he made in the course of his shameful attack upon the right honorable gentleman, and in imputing to him a lack of loyalty. I think that that was one of the most contemptible utterances ever made in this Parliament.

speech.para: The man whom the honorable member for Bradfield sought to defame is a leader who has won public acclaim and who enjoys widespread confidence among the Australian people. Politics becomes a hateful business when those who serve the nation well, and who gain world recognition and honour, are victimized and viciously reviled by men who ought to know better. The standards of honour and conduct of this Parliament demand something better. The Leader of the Opposition speaks for more than one half of the people of this continent and deserves to be heard with respect. In a much shorter period of time than some honorable gentleman opposite expect, the Leader of the Opposition will be Prime Minister aand leader of the Australian nation. This kind of attack seems to be more or less the regular practice of some honorable members on the Government side of the House. In my opinion, such attacks are not only totally unwarranted but also inexcusable because of their lack of good taste. A rather remarkable speech was delivered by a member of the Government, the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton). He sought to rewrite the history of British toryism. It was easy for him to discuss the nature of the political cradle in which he was nurtured.

talk.start.para: - I rise to order. I direct your attention, Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker, to Standing Order 61, which provides that an honorable member shall not read his speech. The honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin) has been in this House for long enough to know that a member shall not read his speech. It is of no use to say that he is using copious notes.
- I think the honorable member for Bonython is referring to his notes.

- I rise to order. Surely it is time that. Standing Order 61 was obeyed. On occasions similar to this, it has been said time and again that only notes are being used. But it is quite obvious that the honorable member for Bonython could not possibly have brought out the many points that he has brought out to-night without referring to most extensive notes which have been prepared, I think, by another member of his party.

- Order! If the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Joske) wishes to dispute the decision of the Chair that the honorable member for Bonython hhas been referring to notes, a certain course of action is open to him.
- I was not disputing the decision of the Chair. I was putting to the Chair the proposition that the Standing Order should be interpreted literally.

- Order! If the honorable member for Balaclava disagrees with my decision, he may take the appropriate action. I have ruled that the honorable member for Bonython is referring to his notes and, therefore, is in order.

- This method of wasting time does not deceive anybody. It is evident that honorable gentlemen opposite, do not like the criticisms that I have made of them and that they recognize their guilt in connexion with the matters to which I have referred. The Minister for Social Services sought to rewrite the history of British toryism. He declared that that line of political thought was responsible for many of the great reforms of earlier times. He said that the conservatism of those early days, with which is associated the liberalism of these days, was responsible for the Bill of Rights, the abolition of slavery and the improvements that were made in the factories and industries of Great Britain at that time. I say that toryism, as well as liberalism, has a very dark record. Who created the conditions in Great Britain under which the bodies of the people were subjected to a form of enslavement and were used in a most vile way with a view to exploitation by people who sought to make profits from them? It was the tories of those days who were responsible for that kind of action by the governing class in the United Kingdom.

- The honorable member for Bradfield spoke yesterday, but he did not do himself much credit. I shall not reply to any interjections that emanate from him. The Minister for Social Services sought to justify the record of governments such as that with which he is associated. He tried to make us believe that those governments had been most beneficent and had been responsible for the great reforms which were the means of liberating the people from enslavement and giving them a much more secure position. Let me say that there were no conditions in the history of Great Britain more vile than those under which women and children were employed in the factories. The Minister sought to justify the actions of this Government on the basis of the record of the party to which I am referring. I say that this Government and previous governments of the same kind have no record of which they can feel proud or about which they can boast. Their whole history is a record of attempts to make possible the exploitation of the many by the few.

speech.para: Let me turn to the statement that was made by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) prior to his departure for overseas. He did not give a great deal of encouragement to us in regard to the international position. He indicated that conditions in the Middle East were causing grave misgivings. He said that the situation in Kashmir was highly dangerous, and that conditions in Asia were giving cause for concern to those who sought to effect a settlement of international differences. But the signs are much more hopeful than the Minister is prepared to admit. During the last week. President Eisenhower replied to a letter that he had received from Marshal Bulganin, the Premier of the Soviet Union. In that reply there was a great deal to encourage the world to believe that progress towards better understanding is being slowly made. I believe that these problems are capable of solution. As a result of my experience in the United Nations, particularly as the chairman of the Security Council, I am satisfied that, provided there is patience and a desire for mutual trust and understanding, every problem likely to be referred to that great international authority is capable of solution. I doubt very much whether honorable members on the Government side have confidence in the ability of the United Nations to discharge the great duties that have been laid upon it. Every effort should be made to induce the peoples of the world to reach an agreement on ways and means to deal with the great menace of atomic warfare. If only there were goodwill on the part of all concerned, such an agreement could be reached.

I am pleased to learn of a growing feeling throughout the world in favour of exchanges of visits by representatives of various countries, not only members of governments, but also persons from many walks of life. By such means better relationships will certainly be secured among the peoples of the world. The Leader of the Opposition has pointed out that after the Potsdam conference in 1945 no meeting of the leaders of the great nations was held until 1955, and, in consequence, the relations between the nations deteriorated to a considerable degree. During that time, there was a far greater sense of insecurity throughout the world than there would have been if more consultations had been held. After that long interval, a conference was held at Geneva at which new and important relations were established between the nations, and I have no doubt that they will be of great benefit.

Friendly relations will also be extended by the recent actions of President Eisenhower. The decisions reached at the Hobart conference of the Australian Labour party, as they have been amplified and supplemented by the Leader of the Opposition, have given a lead to the country in international relations. The Labour party has proved that its thinking is in advance of any thinking that the Government has been capable of, and at present we notice the Government beginning reluctantly to accept many of the principles laid down in that declaration as being the best approach that can be made to international affairs.

The Leader of the Opposition is more in tune with the great needs of the present day - and has proved himself to be so through his declarations of policy on international affairs - than any honorable member on the Government side. Relations between our country and the countries not only of. Asia, but also of other parts of the world, will be improved as the result of greater concentration upon the agencies of the United Nations as is provided in the policy of the Leader of the Opposition, which was enunciated at the Hobart conference. The Labour party's policy properly sets forth methods for the solution of the problem of atomic warfare and other grievous problems.

talk.start.para: R asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development, upon notice -

quote.para: Will he provide the most precise information available as to the proposed inundation of the township of Jindabyne as part of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric project?

question.para: Mr.FAIRHALL - The Minister for National Development has furnished the following reply: -

quote.para: The Snowy Mountains Authority will establish a new township for the residents of Jindabyne. With this in view, the temporary works township near the dam-site, with its water supply, sewerage, electricity and other services, has been planned to incorporate the new permanent township. Present planning provides for the removal of Jindabyne by the middle of 1901, when it is anticipated that portions of the existing township at lower elevations could be in danger of inundation due to the construction of Jindabyne dam. Owners and occupiers have the right to decide whether they prefer a cash settlement as compensation for their respective interests or whether they prefer to transfer to the new town. Transfers to the new town will be based on the guiding principle that the authority will endeavour to effect settlement in such a way that residents will be placed in a position at least comparable with that which they enjoy at present. Invalid and old age pensioners will be given special consideration. As in the case of Adaminaby, the authority works in close collaboration with the Snowy River Shire Council, through a special advisory committee consisting of representatives of the Shire and the Authority. At present the authority is proceeding to buy all vacant land in the township area and is also buying improved properties when requested to do so by owners who for their own reasons wish to dispose of their property.

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister representing the Minister acting for the Minister in charge of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, upon notice -

item.para: Is the Organization still continuing its rain making experiments; if so, what success has it achieved?
Is it devoting any attention to the question of the impact of atomic experiments on the elements and has it come to any conclusions thereon ?

talk.start.para: - The Minister in charge of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization has supplied the following answers to the honorable member's questions : -

item.para: The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization is still actively engaged in a programme of research in cloud and rain physics and in practical experiment on rain making, and the scientific work is resulting in a much clearer understanding of the processes by which rain is formed under different conditions. The results of the practical experiments are very promising, but it is too early at this stage to claim complete success. It will be appreciated that with experiments of this type the statistical aspect is of great importance since it is impossible, to say, with respect to any given operation whether rain would have fallen had the opera tion not been carried out.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization hears no responsibility in connexion with atomic experiments and has not reached any conclusions about their effect, if any, on the weather. This is a matter, however, which is being considered by the World Meteorological Organization. So far this body has not reported on it.
